ArticleTitle.sentence: Nuclear receptor steroidogenic factor 1 regulates the müllerian inhibiting substance gene: a link to the sex determination cascade.

event.clue: Nuclear receptor steroidogenic factor 1 regulates the müllerian inhibiting substance gene: a link to the sex determination cascade.

AbstractText.sentence: Normal male sex differentiation requires that Sertoli cells in the embryonic testes produce müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS), a TGF beta-like hormone that causes müllerian duct regression.
In primary Sertoli cells, the orphan nuclear receptor, steroidogenic factor 1 (SF-1), regulates the MIS gene by binding to a conserved upstream regulatory element.

event.clue: In primary Sertoli cells, the orphan nuclear receptor, steroidogenic factor 1 (SF-1), regulates the MIS gene by binding to a conserved upstream regulatory element.
In primary Sertoli cells, the orphan nuclear receptor, steroidogenic factor 1 (SF-1), regulates the MIS gene by binding to a conserved upstream regulatory element.

AbstractText.sentence: In heterologous (HeLa) cells, MIS gene activation by SF-1 requires removal of the SF-1 ligand-binding domain, implicating a Sertoli cell-specific ligand or cofactor.

event.clue: In heterologous (HeLa) cells, MIS gene activation by SF-1 requires removal of the SF-1 ligand-binding domain, implicating a Sertoli cell-specific ligand or cofactor.
In heterologous (HeLa) cells, MIS gene activation by SF-1 requires removal of the SF-1 ligand-binding domain, implicating a Sertoli cell-specific ligand or cofactor.

AbstractText.sentence: Finally, the sexually dimorphic expression of SF-1 during development coincides with MIS expression and müllerian duct regression.

event.clue: Finally, the sexually dimorphic expression of SF-1 during development coincides with MIS expression and müllerian duct regression.
Finally, the sexually dimorphic expression of SF-1 during development coincides with MIS expression and müllerian duct regression.

AbstractText.sentence: We propose that SF-1 regulates MIS in vivo and participates directly in the process of mammalian sex determination.

event.clue: We propose that SF-1 regulates MIS in vivo and participates directly in the process of mammalian sex determination.
